instruction: How were machine learning models utilized in the evaluation of the potential of infrared spectroscopic microscopy, combined with multivariate analysis, for the rapid detection of ESBL-producing E. coli isolated from urinary-tract infection samples?
Output: Machine learning models were utilized in the evaluation of the potential of infrared spectroscopic microscopy, combined with multivariate analysis, for the rapid detection of ESBL-producing E. coli isolated from urinary-tract infection samples. These models were used to analyze the infrared spectroscopic data obtained from the samples and to classify them as either ESBL-positive or ESBL-negative. The models were trained using a dataset of 837 samples, including 268 ESBL+ and 569 ESBL- samples. The performance of the models was then evaluated based on their ability to accurately classify the samples. The results showed that the machine learning models achieved a 97% success rate, 99% sensitivity, and 94% specificity in detecting ESBL-producing bacteria in just a few minutes following the first culture.
